Fierro b a Dpto. Físicoquimica, Facultad Ciencias Químicas, Universidad de Concepción, Concepción, Chile Dpto. Físicoquimica Facultad Ciencias Químicas Universidad de Concepción Concepción Chile b Instituto Catálisis y Petroleoquímica, ICP-CSIC, Cantoblanco, Madrid, Spain Instituto Catálisis y Petroleoquímica ICP-CSIC Cantoblanco Madrid Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Heterogeneous supported potassium on promoted CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 sol-gel mixed oxides was used as a catalyst for biodiesel production via the transesterification of canola oil with methanol using a batch reactor. These mixed oxides alone do not show any catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction, and the incorporation of potassium increases the catalytic activity, which is greater in the La2O3-promoted catalysts. The improved catalytic activity of the potassium La2O3-promoted catalysts was associated with the partial insertion of lanthanum into alumina with a favorable interaction between the potassium and the oxygenated species of the La2O3-Al2O3 mixed oxide. The larger amount of K2O species in K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 and the lower acidity explain their large production of biodiesel. Moreover, the leaching resistance of potassium is remarkable, with the K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst showing<4% in the first recycle and no more leaching in the four subsequent recycle steps. Keywords Potassium Cerium Lanthanum Biodiesel Leaching 1 Introduction The industrial production of biodiesel is usually carried out by homogeneous catalytic transesterification reactions using basic alkaline catalysts such as NaOH, CH3ONa or KOH [1]. Due to the intrinsic problem associated with homogeneous catalysis in terms of separation and recuperation of the catalyst, significant efforts have been carried out for the heterogenization of the alkaline catalysts. For biodiesel, defined as the mono alkyl ester of long chain of fatty acids derived from triglycerides in vegetables oils or animals fats [2], it is highly desirable to use large triglycerides with low polyphenol contents in the starting material. To optimize the biodiesel production and to avoid secondary reactions such as saponification of the triglyceride, it is also desirable for the starting material to have a low water content. Additionally, the differences in the nature of the triglycerides are related to the nature of the alkyl groups; specifically, the length of the chain of the triglycerides is a key issue for the design of the catalyst. Thus, for triglycerides with higher acidity, an acid catalyst being able to esterify fatty acids must be selected. In contrast, if the starting material is a source of triglycerides with a low acidity, a catalyst with basic characteristics to catalyze the transesterification reaction is needed. Recently, new heterogeneous basic catalysts for use in biodiesel production by transesterification reactions have been reported [3–12]. Among them are the metallic oxides CaO [9,13–17] and MgO [11] that have shown good catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction, as well as other more complex systems, such as KNO3/Al2O3 [18], K2CO3/Al2O3 [19], Mg/ZrO2 [20], Ag/Al2O3 [21], sodium titanate nanotubes [6], silica [10], resin catalyst [22] and hydrotalcites [11]. Most of them have activity problems, such as the recycling of heterogeneous catalysts, because the leaching of metal is responsible for leading the pathway of the reaction by the homogeneous system [19,23]. Considering that potassium is a promising element in transesterification reactions [13,24], it is here proposed to prepare new heterogeneous basic potassium-promoted alumina-supported catalysts for transesterification reactions. Among the well-known promoters, CeO2 and La2O3 [25–30] have received great attention due to the larger redox properties, high oxygen transport capacity and oxygen storage [31] for the former and large thermally stability and basic characteristics for the latter. On the basis of the above reasoning, we report the effect of the nature (CeO2 and La2O3) and the content (3 and 5%) of sol-gel mixed oxides used as a support to prepare 10wt% of potassium CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts and evaluated in a transesterification reaction using canola oil as a model system for the production of biodiesel. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation The syntheses of sol-gel 3%CeO2/Al2O3, 5%CeO2/Al2O3, 3%La2O3/Al2O3 and 5%La2O3/Al2O3 mixed oxides were carried out from aluminum trisec-butoxide and the respective lanthanum and cerium acetylacetonates. The procedure consisted of maintaining the respective precursors of Ce and La under reflux and agitation at 70°C in distilled water and 2-butanol and maintaining a water/alcohol molar ratio of 1:4 at pH 7. The obtained materials were subjected to vacuum drying at 100°C and subsequent air calcination at 600°C for 6h. Subsequently, a potassium impregnation procedure in order to obtain three atoms of K nm−2 was carried out on the sol gel mixed oxides, followed by another calcination procedure in air at 600°C for 6h. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface areas were calculated using the BET method from the nitrogen adsorption isotherms using Tri Star II 3020 equipment. Diffraction X ray measurements were conducted using a Rigaku diffractometer (CuΚαλ=0, 15406nm and Ni filter), and atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) was performed using a PerkinElmer 3100 absorptiometer. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) and ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD) profiles were performed using a TPR/TPD 2900 Micromeritics system with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the reduction experiment, the samples (50mg) were thermally treated under a He flow at 110°C for 30min to remove water and other contaminants. The reduction profiles were recorded with a 5% H2/Ar flow at 50mLmin−1 at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 700°C. For the O2-TPD experiments, the samples were preheated in an O2 flow for 1h at 700°C, cooled to room temperature in the same atmosphere, and then switched to a helium flow with the oxygen desorption monitored using a TCD. For the NH3-TPD experiments, the catalyst surface was saturated at 100°C with ammonia pulses and cooled to room temperature, and once the baseline was restored, the temperature was linearly increased to 800°C. The XPS measurements were performed using a VG Escalab 200R electron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and Mg Kα (1253.6eV) X-ray source. Prior to analysis, the samples were outgassed at 300°C for 1h in a vacuum chamber. Charging effects were corrected by taking the C1s peak of adventitious carbon at 284.8eV. The peaks were deconvoluted into several components assuming a Gaussian/Lorentzian shape. 2.3 Catalytic activity The transesterification reaction to produce biodiesel was carried out using commercial canola oil free of impurities and humidity as a model system. The reaction was conducted in a flask reactor under constant reflux of methanol at 65°C with 1.2g of catalyst at atmospheric pressure and 230rpm of agitation. External diffusion was excluded through a series of mass transfer tests, and thus ignored because the particle size was less than 0.4mm (i.e., 40–60mesh). The samples taken from the reactor were deposited in a mixture of 1.0M HCl and eicosane/hexane at a molar ratio of 1:1 and subsequently centrifuged for 2min at 6000rpm. From the organic phase, 1μL was extracted and injected into a Perkin Elmer Gas Chromatography system, Clarus@ 680 model, which includes a Supelco Omega Watt 250 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Atomic absorption spectroscopy The elemental composition of K in the potassium supported catalysts is compiled in Table 1 for the CeO2-Al2O3 series and Table 2 for the corresponding La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst. The obtained values are similar to the nominal one (10wt%K), indicating no potassium loss during the synthesis. 3.2 Surface area Table 1 compiles the surface area for the CeO2-Al2O3, and Table 2 contains the corresponding values for the La2O3-Al2O3 series. For the sol gel CeO2-Al2O3 oxides, a specific area of ∼200m2 g−1 is observed. Once the alkali is incorporated, a significant decrease is detected in the K2O/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts, indicating that after the incorporation of the potassium, the porosity of the support is blocked for K2O. The same behavior is observed in the La2O3-Al2O3 series (Table 2) and in previously reported results for 14wt% CaO/SBA15 catalysts [13]. Despite the larger surface areas (200–300m2 g−1) of the starting sol gel CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 mixed oxides, the decrease upon potassium incorporation produces potassium-supported catalysts with surface areas that are lower and similar to those of the starting materials (∼100m2 g−1) and larger than those of other potassium titanate-supported catalysts [13,24]. 3.3 Temperature programmed reduction Fig. 1 a) shows the reduction profiles for the CeO2-Al2O3 series, and Fig. 1b) shows the corresponding data for La2O3-Al2O3. It is clear that neither CeO2-Al2O3 nor La2O3-Al2O3 sol gel oxides show any well-defined reduction peaks, indicating that they are almost non-reducible materials, at least at the studied temperature. For CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts, the partial reduction of Ce4+/Ce3+ between 200°C and 550°C [31,32] cannot be discounted due to a reduction peak over 400°C for the CeO2-Al2O3 mixed oxides in Fig. 1a). In contrast, for the potassium supported catalysts, a well-defined reduction peak starting at 400°C and centered at 520°C is detected. Because Jimenez et al. [33] and Pellegrini et al. [34] reported the reduction of potassium carbonate species at 400°C and between 350 and 550°C, the obtained profile also confirms the presence of potassium in the prepared catalysts. A shift in the maximum reduction peak assigned to potassium from 502°C in K2O/5CeO2 to 521°C for K2O/3CeO2 (Fig. 1a) is observed. The opposite effect is observed for K2O/5La2O3, which appears at a higher temperature than that for K2O/3La2O3 (Fig. 1b), which indicates differences in potassium dispersion or surface interactions with the sol gel mixed oxide. Quantification of the area under the curve determines H2 consumption by deconvolution of the area using a Lorentzian distribution type, and the obtained results are compiled in Table 1 for the CeO2-Al2O3 and Table 2 for the La2O3-Al2O3 series. Considering that AAS indicates a 9wt% of K, the theoretical hydrogen consumption of 1.1mmol H2 g−1 for the complete reduction of K+ can be considered to calculate the extent of reduction of the catalysts, assuming no hydrogen consumption by the support (Fig. 1). The 65% of the reduction of the surface (K+) in K2O/5La2O3 indicates greater availability of the active species as catalytic sites. 3.4 Temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen In general, oxidative materials desorb oxygen at different temperatures. Physically adsorbed oxygen desorbs at temperatures lower than 100°C, and chemically adsorbed oxygen desorbs between 200°C and 500°C [35]. For crystalline structures, lattice oxygen atoms desorb at temperatures of up to 600°C. Fig. 2 a) and b) displays the oxygen desorption profiles for the CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3, respectively. Some differences in the maximum desorbed temperatures are shown, with almost no differences in the shape of the profiles. For the CeO2-Al2O3 mixed oxide (Fig. 2a), only chemisorbed oxygen desorbed from 200°C to 400°C is observed, whereas for the La2O3-Al2O3 series (Fig. 2b), the desorbed peaks shift towards lower temperatures. The larger desorption peak for the CeO2-Al2O3 mixed oxide can be attributed to the redox properties of CeO2 generating vacancies and allowing a higher mobility of the oxygen species [36,37], whereas the presence of physisorbed and chemisorbed oxygen species for the La2O3-Al2O3 series (Fig. 2b) are closely related to the easy carbonation of lanthanum species [38,39]. When the alkali is incorporated, both series shift towards higher temperatures of the maximum desorption peak. TPD-MS experiments confirm that the evolved gas and the He flow only contain oxygen; thus, deconvolution of the oxygen desorption curves using a Lorentzian line shape allows the calculation of the desorbed oxygen in the corresponding temperature range. Table 1 shows the total desorbed oxygen for CeO2-Al2O3 and Table 2 shows the corresponding data for La2O3-Al2O3. For the CeO2-Al2O3 series (Table 1), similar oxygen desorbed values indicate almost no effect of the potassium species on the amount of desorbed oxygen, indicative of less interaction between potassium and the oxidized species. However, for the La2O3-Al2O3 series, the large decrease in the desorbed oxygen upon the addition of potassium indicates an enhancement of the interaction between the alkali with the oxygenated species, in agreement with previous reported results regarding the insertion of La3+ into Al2O3 [25]. 3.5 X-ray diffraction Fig. 3 a) shows the X-ray diffractograms for the CeO2-Al2O3 series, and the corresponding data for La2O3-Al2O3 is in Fig. 3b). Regarding the CeO2-Al2O3 mixed oxides (Fig. 3a), only diffraction peaks corresponding to the CeO2 fluorite structure (43-1002) [40] and Al2O3 (10-0425) [25,41] are detected. The absence of diffraction peaks for potassium indicates that the crystalline potassium species has a larger degree of dispersion, too small to be detectable or present in an amorphous form. With regard to the La2O3-Al2O3 series (Fig. 3b), crystalline La2O3 with a hexagonal structure (40-1281) was detected only for 5La2O3 [25,37]. Considering the differences in the La2O3 content, the appearance of the La2O3 diffraction peak for the larger lanthanum content is expected. With regard to potassium, it is noticeable that potassium species are detected only as K2O (77-2151) for the K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst. Because AAS indicates a 9wt% of K content for all of the prepared catalysts, the appearance of K2O indicates of lower dispersion degree or large availability. Considering the similarity of the reduction profiles (Fig. 1) and the large extent of reduction of the potassium species in K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3, it can be extrapolated that potassium should also be present as K2O in a lower extent for potassium supported in the 3CeO2-Al2O3, 5CeO2-Al2O3 and 3La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts. 3.6 Ammonium temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) The measurement of acid strength by NH3-TPD assumes that the temperature of the maximum desorption rate is a rough measure of the acid strength of the sorption sites. It has been proposed that physically adsorbed and hydrogen-bonded NH3 will desorbed at ≤150°C [42] and NH3 bound to acid sites will desorb at T>150°C; weak bonds correspond to T<250°C and moderate to strong bonds corresponds to T>250°C [43]. The NH3 desorption profiles shown in Fig. 4 indicates differences upon the addition of the promoter. For the larger 5% CeO2 and 5% La2O3 promoted catalyst, it can be seen total disappearance of strong and medium acid sites. Considering that alumina is an acid support, the observed behavior should be attribute to surface coverage of alumina by the non-acidic CeO2 [44] and La2O3 [39] oxides. The total amount of desorbed NH3 was estimated with a confidence level of 94% by deconvoluting the peaks, and the data are summarized in Tables 1 and 2. The obtained values correspond to non-acid catalyst [2,43,45], and the further decrease for the larger 5% CeO2 and 5% La2O3 promoted catalyst is an expecting result according to the basic nature of the prepared catalyst. Moreover, the observed trend could be also associated with CeO2 and La2O3 dispersion and chemical interaction between Ce-Al and La-Al as it has been reported previously in close relation with hydrogenation catalytic reactions [37,44] 3.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy For the potassium-supported catalysts, the Ce core-levels spectra are shown in Fig. 5 a), and the corresponding La 3d are presented in Fig. 5b). The spectra of Al 2p do not change from the reported 74.5eV, and the O 1s binding energies (BE) shown in Table 1 and 2 correspond to weakly bonded surface oxygen atoms [46]. In Fig. 5a), the Ce spectra display a single peak attributed to Ce4+ and multiplets and satellite peaks previously reported for Ce3+ [47]. The core-level spectra of Ce4+ and Ce3+ at 882.3 [48] and 885.3eV [49], respectively, allow differentiation of the surface contributions, and the obtained BE values are presented in Table 1. The presence of surface Ce4+ and Ce3+ is in agreement with previous reports for CeO2 [50]. In Fig. 5b), the most intense peak of La3d5/2 shows two components at 834.9eV and 838.1eV, both attributed to La3+ [38]. The shift of the reported signal of La3+at 834.9eV [51–53] indicates the insertion of lanthanum into the Al2O3 matrix or lanthanum highly dispersed as small particles inside the Al2O3 bulk [37]. In Table 3 , the Ce/Al and La/Al atomic surface ratios are shown. The similar nominal and surface composition Ce/Al ratio for potassium 3CeO2-Al2O3 indicates a regular distribution of CeO2 as a monolayer, and the slight increase in the Ce/Al surface ratio from 3%CeO2 to 5%CeO2-Al2O3 indicates a similar surface coverage by CeO2, which remains like patches on the surface. However, partial insertion of Al3+ (0.053nm) into the CeO2 lattice (Ce4+ 0.097nm) cannot be discounted, as it has been reported previously [36]. In the La2O3 series, the surface ratios are lower than the nominal values for both catalysts. The decrease in the La/Al surface ratio can be attributed to a decrease in surface La by the easy incorporation of Al3+ into the lanthanum oxide and the partial insertion into the La2O3 lattice [37,39] or an inter-diffusion process between Al3+ (0.053nm) and La3+ (0.122nm) ions in a La2O3-Al2O3 solid solution [25]. The core level spectra for potassium K2p shown in Fig. 6 displays a similar doublet for the potassium supported catalysts. The respective BE for K2p3/2 shown in Table 1 and 2 indicates almost the same BE values of 293.6 ±0.2eV for the K2O/5CeO2, K2O/3CeO2 and K2O/3La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts, whereas a shift towards lower BE up to 292.8eV for K2O/5La2O3 was detected. For K+ species, BE values of 292.4eV for K/CeO2 [54], 293.2eV for La1-xKxMnO3+δ [55] and 293.49eV and 292.89eV BE for 10%K2O/SiO2 and 35% K2O/SiO2, respectively, have been reported. These discrepancies have been noted by Sawyer et al. [56], considering that the highly volatile surface K+ species are associated with K2O with different energetic sites due to differences in electron densities over the surface K+ species. Therefore, the lower BE values of the K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts indicate a higher electronic mobility surface of K2O species with lower electronic density [54]. With regard to the surface K/La+Al and K/Ce+La ratio shown in Table 3, the values are larger than the nominal composition without a clear dependence on the differences in the Ce/Al and La/Al atomic surface ratios. 3.8 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity in biodiesel conversion will be monitored in a transesterification reaction using commercial canola oil as a model system. Biodiesel is defined as fatty acid methyl ester (FAMES) formation; therefore, prior to the heterogeneous catalytic activity measurements, is necessary to determine the fatty acid composition of the commercial canola oil. The selected procedure was GC analysis of the homogeneous reaction, carried out three times, to determine with an error of 7.6% the methyl ester composition [57]. A referential canola oil composition [58] is included in Table 4 to validate the nature of the selected commercial canola oil as model system for the transesterification reaction. Fig. 7 shows the biodiesel conversion with respect to reaction time for the prepared heterogeneous potassium supported catalysts. It can be seen in Fig. 7 that the short induction time indicates that there is no requirement for previous activation, such as the formation of CH3O− species in a reaction medium, as has been reported for K/Al2O3 [4,19] and nanocrystalline MgO catalysts [59]. In Fig. 7a), a similar shape of conversion levels with respect to time is clearly seen, with larger biodiesel conversion at 2h for the K2O/5CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst. With regard to Fig. 7b, the largest catalytic activity is obtained for the K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts, reaching a total biodiesel conversion of 100% at 2h of reaction. The obtained biodiesel conversion at the same reaction time is shown in Table 3. The activity measurements of the sol gel mixed oxides (CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3) do not show any activity in the transesterification reaction (shown in the Supplementary Material). Therefore, the observed catalytic behavior can be attributed to the potassium species. Considering the previous characterization results, the larger catalytic activity of the potassium supported on the La2O3-Al2O3 sol gel mixed oxides can be attributed to the insertion of lanthanum in the alumina, as detected by XRD and XPS, favoring a closer interaction between potassium and the oxidized species. Meanwhile, in the CeO2 Al2O3 series, the agglomerates of CeO2 as patches and the lower insertion of Al3+ into the CeO2 lattice do not allow a desirable chemical environment for the K2O species, decreasing the catalytic activity in biodiesel conversion. The largest biodiesel conversion for K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 can be attributed to the larger K2O content detected by TPR and XRD and the deficient environment of K2O species detected by XPS. Therefore, it is proposed that in the prepared K2O catalysts, the surface electronic deficient K+ will be adequate sites for a dissociative adsorption of methanol, analogous to the methanol adsorption in MgO catalysts reported by Montero [59]. For this catalyst, the deficient K2O actives sites for CH3O− and hydroxide species formation, as well as the lowest acidity favoring the adsorption of H+ on the Lewis base centers (O2−) and releasing CH3O− in the reaction medium are responsible for their catalytic activity. The obtained values of biodiesel conversion from transesterification reaction shown in Table 3 are similar to those of other heterogeneous catalysts, such as CaO/SBA15 (65% conversion at 1h) [12], potassium titanate (100% of conversion at 2h) [57], and larger than those of Mg Al hydrotalcites (67% of conversion at 9h) [11] and CaO/SnO2 (89% of conversion at 6h) [12]. 3.9 Catalyst reusability The recycled catalyst activity is an attractive property in order to reduce the process costs and meet environmental regulations. Therefore, the superior catalyst of each series was selected to evaluate the reusability capacity. After the catalytic reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation at 6000rpm to separate the organic from the aqueous phase, followed by washing and filtering six times with methanol, drying at 60°C and calcination at 600°C for 6h to remove adsorbed organic species previous to reuse under the same reaction conditions. The recycle processes were carried out four times, and the biodiesel conversion values (mol %) as a function of the recycle are shown in Fig. 8 a) for K2O/5CeO2-Al2O3 and Fig. 8b) for K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3. For a better comparison, the first catalytic run was included. K2O/5CeO2-Al2O3 shows a significant loss of activity from the first to the following recycle. In contrast, only a slight decrease in the catalytic activity is detected for K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 for the first recycle, followed by an almost constant catalytic activity. The decrease in the catalytic activity in the recycles can be attributed to the leaching of the potassium species, as has been previously reported for impregnated potassium catalysts [23]. To confirm this result, at the end of the catalytic transesterification reaction performed with fresh catalyst, the organic phases were separated from the aqueous phase by centrifugation, and the presence of potassium species in the aqueous phase was determined by AAS. The determination of K+ in the aqueous phase post reaction was 220 and 68.8mgL−1 for K2O/5CeO2-Al2O3 and K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 that correspond to 14% and 4% of potassium leaching, respectively. It is proposed that for K2O/5CeO2-Al2O3, the potassium species lixiviated during the reaction and may also remain as suspended colloids, acting as homogeneous catalysts; in contrast, for K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3, the reaction proceeds mainly by the heterogeneous route. 4 Conclusions Sol-gel CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 mixed oxides were fully prepared to be used as supports to prepare actives heterogeneous K2O supported catalysts for biodiesel production via the transesterification of canola oil. The differences in the interaction of K2O with the sol gel mixed oxides explain the differences in catalytic activity and the leaching of the potassium species of the prepared catalysts. For potassium supported on CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts, the lower interaction of the K+ species with patches of CeO2, closer to the monolayer for K2O/3CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts facilitate the leaching of potassium to the aqueous phase, allowing the occurrence of a homogeneous route over the heterogeneous one, with the complete loss of activity in the recycles. However, for potassium supported on La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts, the proposed inter-diffusion process between the Al3+ and La3+ ions increases the interaction between K2O with the La2O3-Al2O3 solid solution, increasing the catalytic activity and decreasing the well-known K leaching present to a large extent in the impregnated supported catalysts. The larger extent of K2O species in K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 and the lower acidity explain their large production of biodiesel. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous supported potassium on promoted CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 sol-gel mixed oxides was used as a catalyst for biodiesel production via the transesterification of canola oil with methanol using a batch reactor. These mixed oxides alone do not show any catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction, and the incorporation of potassium increases the catalytic activity, which is greater in the La2O3-promoted catalysts. The improved catalytic activity of the potassium La2O3-promoted catalysts was associated with the partial insertion of lanthanum into alumina with a favorable interaction between the potassium and the oxygenated species of the La2O3-Al2O3 mixed oxide. The larger amount of K2O species in K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 and the lower acidity explain their large production of biodiesel. Moreover, the leaching resistance of potassium is remarkable, with the K2O/5La2O3-Al2O3 catalyst showing<4% in the first recycle and no more leaching in the four subsequent recycle steps.
coredata.dc:title: K2O supported on sol-gel CeO2-Al2O3 and La2O3-Al2O3 catalysts for the transesterification reaction of canola oil
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
